{'document_id': ['0000135', '0000135', '0000135', '0000135'], 'document_source': ['NIDDK', 'NIDDK', 'NIDDK', 'NIDDK'], 'document_url': ['http://www.niddk.nih.gov/health-information/health-topics/kidney-disease/acquired-cystic-kidney-disease/Pages/facts.aspx', 'http://www.niddk.nih.gov/health-information/health-topics/kidney-disease/acquired-cystic-kidney-disease/Pages/facts.aspx', 'http://www.niddk.nih.gov/health-information/health-topics/kidney-disease/acquired-cystic-kidney-disease/Pages/facts.aspx', 'http://www.niddk.nih.gov/health-information/health-topics/kidney-disease/acquired-cystic-kidney-disease/Pages/facts.aspx'], 'category': [None, None, None, None], 'umls_cui': ['C3160745|C1691228|C0022679', 'C3160745|C1691228|C0022679', 'C3160745|C1691228|C0022679', 'C3160745|C1691228|C0022679'], 'umls_semantic_types': ['T047', 'T047', 'T047', 'T047'], 'umls_semantic_group': ['Disorders', 'Disorders', 'Disorders', 'Disorders'], 'synonyms': [None, None, None, None], 'question_id': ['0000135-2', '0000135-3', '0000135-4', '0000135-5'], 'question_focus': ['Acquired Cystic Kidney Disease', 'Acquired Cystic Kidney Disease', 'Acquired Cystic Kidney Disease', 'Acquired Cystic Kidney Disease'], 'question_type': ['information', 'frequency', 'causes', 'symptoms'], 'question': ['What is (are) Acquired Cystic Kidney Disease ?', 'How many people are affected by Acquired Cystic Kidney Disease ?', 'What causes Acquired Cystic Kidney Disease ?', 'What are the symptoms of Acquired Cystic Kidney Disease ?'], 'answer': ['Acquired cystic kidney disease differs from PKD in several ways. Unlike acquired cystic kidney disease, PKD is a genetic, or inherited, disorder that can cause complications such as high blood pressure and problems with blood vessels in the brain and heart.
                
The following chart lists the differences:
                
People with Polycystic Kidney Disease   - are born with a gene that causes the disease   - have enlarged kidneys   - develop cysts in the liver and other parts of the body   People with Acquired Cystic Kidney Disease   - do not have a disease-causing gene   - have kidneys that are normal-sized or smaller   - do not form cysts in other parts of the body
                
In addition, for people with PKD, the presence of cysts marks the onset of their disease, while people with acquired cystic kidney disease already have CKD when they develop cysts.
                
More information is provided in the NIDDK health topic, Polycystic Kidney Disease.', 'Acquired cystic kidney disease becomes more common the longer a person has CKD.
                
- About 7 to 22 percent of people with CKD already have acquired cystic kidney disease before starting dialysis treatments.  - Almost 60 percent of people on dialysis for 2 to 4 years develop acquired cystic kidney disease.1  - About 90 percent of people on dialysis for 8 years develop acquired cystic kidney disease.1', 'Researchers do not fully understand what causes cysts to grow in the kidneys of people with CKD. The fact that these cysts occur only in the kidneys and not in other parts of the body, as in PKD, indicates that the processes that lead to cyst formation take place primarily inside the kidneys.2', 'A person with acquired cystic kidney disease often has no symptoms. However, the complications of acquired cystic kidney disease can have signs and symptoms.']}
